title: Meet and Eat
description: Time to kick off camp! Join us for some snacks and getting to know your fellow campers!

title: Arduino 101
description: Learn the very basics of how to program with the popular platform for physical computing projects. If you took the “Hello, Arduino” session on Monday night, this session will cover that information, but also delve deeper into the topics of digital input and output as well as analog input and output.

title: Introduction to Max/MSP/Jitter
description: Max/MSP/Jitter is a multimedia authoring environment that enables you to create programs for real-time manipulation of media (data, audio, video, 3d). It is used in performance and installations by artists, composers, and people just like you!

title: Pop-up books and paper circuits
description: Pop-up engineering is really fun and extremely satisfying – for adults and for kids. But how might we use electricity to change the idea of what “interactive” books can be? In this session, participants will create pop-up cards that use the affordances of our materials to really investigate how circuits can change the idea of what a book can be. We’ll also consider where soft circuits are going by looking at examples in toys and wearable technologies.

title: exploring biomimicry
description: This 2-hour workshop on biomimicry will address nature as inspiration for design and technological solutions. We will consider the biological and natural world, and work hands on to create quick prototypes using paper, pen, and some building materials, on topics that might include re-designing social networks, mapping urban spaces, and re-defining user interfaces.

title: iOS Boot Camp
description: Getting started with the iPhone, iPad or iPod touch using Apple’s native development tools. This is a three hour hands on workshop session that should get you beyond the “Hello World” stage and leave you with code running on you device and on to the interesting stuff. We’ll hopefully move on to playing around with the onboard sensors, or perhaps the map and location frameworks, depending on what people in the class would rather do with the time.

title: Product Design/DigiFab
description: We will be covering design tools (software and hardware) for digital fabrication.

title: Getting Started with Raspberry Pi
description: Learn the fundamentals of Raspberry Pi, the $35 learning computer and why people are so excited about it. This workshop will be a demo of the platform and a Raspberry Pi is not needed to participate.

title: Shop Safety!
description: Get Shop certified!

title: Introduction to Soft Circuits
description: In this class, we will go over conductive materials used in creating soft circuits, such as different thread, fabrics, inks and fasteners, along with looking at microcontrollers designed specifically for wearable electronics. Projects that have been created utilizing these techniques will also be shown. We will then create a simple soft circuit with a switch and that lights up a LED. Attendees will have the chance to learn or expand on basic hand sewing techniques and experience working with new materials and skills.

title: Early version – From Story to Tech: a methodology project
description: Advanced, earlier date of my presentation on the 17th for those of you who wish to get ideas for your Camp projects a little sooner.

title: AT&T AdWorks Lab Tour
description: I’ll give a quick and informal tour of the AdWorks Media Lab.  We’ll look at how we used Cinder to create some very cool (at least we think so!) data visualizations and explain how we developed the narrative for the entire space.  You can see the pool table that will soon be transformed into a completely, interactive experience!    Lastly, you’ll also get a sneak peek at the redesign that we’re currently doing that will launch in September.

title: Intro to After Effects
description: I’ll be attending.

title: Hello PhoneGap
description: The miracle of mobile computing has arrived. Exceedingly powerful computers, seamlessly networked and with a variety of in-built sensors… all right in your pocket.PhoneGap is an open source framework that lets you program cross-platform mobile phone apps using HTML, Javascript and CSS. Providing a Javascript API to access  the accelerometer, GPS, notifications, and other hardware capabilities of your phone, you can write your code once and deploy the app to Android, iPhone, Blackberry and several other platforms.

title: Intro to Makerbotting
description: Learn how to go from file to print. In this lightning session, you will learn how to calibrate a MakerBot, prepare a 3D file (STL) using MakerWare, and then print it on the machines. That’s all there is to it!
comment: Same here. I would love to come, but it’s just in the middle of PhoneGap

title: Field trip to goveners island for the opening of Figment NYC 2013.
description: GIVEN THE RAIN I AM RESCHEDULING THIS TO SUNDAY….
comment: That sound wonderful. I’m in   (though it is really close to the after affect intro, so might go check it out later on that day)

title: Wearables Hack Day
description: Do you sew? Do you play with microcontrollers? Then join us for ITP Camp wearables hack day!

title: Github
description: What will the session cover?

title: Build a music visualizer from scratch in Processing
description: So!  Sunday night, after you’ve hacked some wearables, get down and dirty with an excellent intermediate level processing session on crafting a music visualizer.  I find it’s easiest to learn how to do something new when you have a project to try it with, so lets make a music visualizer!

title: Don’t Go Back to School–independent learning for everybody
description: Forget education reform, let’s transform learning itself! I’m excited to share the research that went into my recently published handbook on independent learning called Don’t Go Back to School, based on interviews with 100 independent learners. Let’s talk about how independent learning works, and how to get more people doing it and taking it seriously, and how it fits into the future of education, daily life, and the world we want to live in. My next contribution to the cause will be a set of guidelines for learning oriented working groups. I’d love to hear your approaches.

title: Really Big Video Part 1
description: This session will introduce Big Building Mapping and Video Projection. I will begin by showing examples of site-specific and video mapping pieces and then we will map a real building using a spatial scan in Mad Mapper. For homework each camper will get a scan to work from and some tips on how to create giant projections. Part 2 of the session will allow campers to showcase their mapped work projected 3 stories tall on an actual building on broadway.

title: Crazy Data Circles with d3.js
Experiment Design Workshop
description: Designing a proper experiment is not a trivial task: and the questions to ask are dependent on your field of study.  In this workshop we will discuss the design of usability studies and scientific studies, and how to use science to get at the truth of the matter your interested in

title: Turning on the lathe
description: **YOU MUST HAVE HAD A SHOP SAFETY TRAINING IN ORDER TO TAKE THIS CLASS.  NO EXCEPTIONS.**

title: Who’s your data? : A guide to Social Network mapping for fun, self knowledge and community building in the digital age.
Streaming Kart 101
description: Want to learn how to use the fabled ITP Live Streaming rig? Interested in Live Streaming in general?

title: UX Skill – Responsive Design Process
description: Do you create UX documents in Omnigraffle, Visio, InDesign, Axure or Illustrator?  Does the design team still create Photoshop PSD files to hand off to the developer?  That no longer works in the responsive design world we live in.

title: Intro to Scratch (and Makey Makey)
description: Scratch is a free program geared towards teaching kids introductory programming skills through gamemaking and animation. It can be paired easily with the Makey Makey, an extremely easy-to-use microcontroller that can turn anything into a keyboard. Come check it out!

title: “Noticing” Workshop
description: This workshop teaches techniques and tools for noticing—seeing, hearing and comprehending something new. In a short series of exercises we’ll explore the observation process in an array of domains, from cognitive psychology to ethnography and drawing to data collection, with techniques for reaching that moment we all crave: when something unexpected and terrific bursts forward into consciousness. Participants will leave with their eyes wide open to the inspirations and complexity that surround us all and their minds full of techniques for learning more.

title: TinkerCAD – 3D Design for Toddlers
description: This is the easiest 3D design program out there. I use it to teach 3D design and printing to toddlers. Seriously.

title: Rest Of You: Digital Edition
description: Life is what happens to you will you are busy doing other things.  You pay attention to a small part of your experience when it is the rest of you that is more important.  The Rest of You is a class about trying to get a better picture of those parts that you don’t pay attention to.  This session will zero in on one week of work in the Rest Of You class that tries to cull through your digital footprint to give you a more accurate picture of yourself and perhaps suggest some interventions to change the rest of you.    Here are some assignments from the digital week of this class http://itp.nyu.edu/~dbo3/roy/?cat=12

title: Guest Speaker: Clive Thompson – “the new literacies”
Akimitsu Sadoi – LED Artist Workshop
description: Aki has offered to do a build workshop which should be quite fun and you’ll have something to take with you. It’s the simplest circuit with the least number of components (see image below). Yet it does share the same technical principle (multiplex LED drive with PWM) with more complex designs of his. He also think it’s a good material to get started with surface mount soldering.

title: Introduction to Rhino
description: Thank you for signing up, I’m looking forward to meeting you all.

title: Nudgeables Workshop
description: Sometimes we use secret codes to communicate with our friends, partners, or colleagues while in the company of a larger group of people: a nudge, a cough, a scratch of the nose; something that says “I’m thinking of you…”, “Save me from this conversation!”, or “Let’s get out of here!”.  What if our clothing could communicate these messages for us?

title: How to Teach Yourself How to Code
description: Led by a person still learning how to code, this session-discussion will explore methods for teaching yourself how to code. I’ve been a bit dissatisfied with the resources currently available, and aim to develop a workshop presenting a framework of tools to scaffold self-teaching for those without a STEM background.

title: Intel Perceptual Computing Lab
description: Hear about the latest projects from the Intel Perceptual Computing Lab!

title: End-of-Camp Shindig
description: Half show & tell, half party, the End of Camp Shindig is an opportunity to celebrate the month we’ve spent together and share what we’ve created.
